title: 111_hr2110
content: The Act is titled the "Mobile Workforce State Income Tax Fairness and Simplification Act" and it limits state withholding and taxation of employee income. The "Mobile Workforce State Income Tax Fairness and Simplification Act" limits state income tax withholding and reporting for employees working in multiple states. Wages are only subject to income tax in the state of residence and the state where the employee works for more than 30 days in a calendar year. The "Mobile Workforce State Income Tax Fairness and Simplification Act" limits state income tax withholding and reporting for employees working in multiple states. Income tax withholding applies to wages earned as of the commencement date of duties in the State during the calendar year. Employers can rely on an employee's time estimate in the States where duties are performed, as long as there is no fraud or collusion to evade tax. Maintaining records of employee locations for business purposes does not affect an employer's ability to rely on them. The "Mobile Workforce State Income Tax Fairness and Simplification Act" allows employers to rely on an employee's time estimate for tax purposes if there is no fraud. Employers can use data from a time and attendance system to track employee duties instead of relying on the employee's determination. Definitions and special rules apply for determining presence and employment duties within a State. The Act defines rules for determining an employee's presence and employment duties within a State. If an employee performs duties in multiple states in one day, the preponderance of duties is considered in the nonresident state. Transit time does not count towards determining location. The term "employee" is defined by the State where duties are performed, excluding professional athletes, entertainers, and certain public figures. A professional athlete is someone who receives payment for services in a professional athletic event, while a professional entertainer is paid for performing as an entertainer. The term "certain public figures" refers to prominent individuals who provide services for payment at specific events, such as giving speeches. The term "figures" refers to individuals who provide services for payment at specific events, such as speeches. The term "employer" is defined as per the Internal Revenue Code or by the State where duties are performed. The term "State" refers to the several States of the United States. The term "time and attendance system" is a system where employees record their work location daily when working outside their state. The term "time and attendance system" requires employees to record their work location daily when working outside their state, and the employer uses this data to allocate wages between taxing jurisdictions. "Wages or other remuneration" is defined by the State where employment duties are performed. The Act will be effective starting January 1, 2011.
